title: Eerie Elementary: The School Is Alive
author: Jack Chabert

questions.question: What is Sam Graves chosen to be at school?
questions.explanation: Sam is chosen to be a hall monitor at Eerie Elementary.

questions.question: What are the names of Sam's two best friends?
questions.explanation: Sam's best friends are Antonio and Lucy.

questions.question: What color is the hall monitor sash that Sam has to wear?
questions.explanation: Sam has to wear a shiny orange sash as hall monitor.

questions.question: Who is the old man that takes care of the school?
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe is the old man who takes care of Eerie Elementary.

questions.question: What is the name of their teacher?
questions.explanation: Ms. Grinker is Sam's classroom teacher.

questions.question: What play is the class putting on?
questions.explanation: The class is performing Peter Pan for Friday's play.

questions.question: Who plays Peter Pan in the school play?
questions.explanation: Antonio plays the role of Peter Pan.

questions.question: Who plays Wendy in the school play?
questions.explanation: Lucy plays Wendy in the Peter Pan play.

questions.question: What character does Sam play in Peter Pan?
questions.explanation: Sam plays Noodler, one of Captain Hook's friendly pirates.

questions.question: What does Antonio always carry in his pocket for good luck?
options: A peanut butter and jelly sandwich
questions.explanation: Antonio always carries a peanut butter and jelly sandwich in his pocket as his lucky charm.

questions.question: What first tries to eat Sam at the playground?
questions.explanation: Sam's feet start sinking into quicksand on the playground.

questions.question: Who saves Sam from the quicksand?
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe grabs Sam's wrist and yanks him free from the quicksand.

questions.question: What breaks through the classroom window?
questions.explanation: The oak tree's long, twisted branch crashes through the window and grabs Sam.

questions.question: What attacks Sam in the hallway at night?
questions.explanation: A fire hose comes to life and whips around, attacking Sam.

questions.question: How does Sam stop the fire hose?
options: He ties it in a knot
questions.explanation: Sam grabs the hose and ties it like a giant shoelace, stopping it.

questions.question: What sound does Sam hear from the clock that scares him?
questions.explanation: The clock changes from tick-tock to 'ba-bump, ba-bump' - the sound of a beating heart.

questions.question: Where does Mr. Nekobe take Sam to train?
options: A secret room behind the janitor's closet
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe has a secret room hidden behind the janitor's closet.

questions.question: What is the training machine made of?
options: Old refrigerator, lockers, and school parts
questions.explanation: The machine is made of an old refrigerator, pieces of vending machine, lockers, and hockey sticks.

questions.question: What does Mr. Nekobe tell Sam about the school?
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe reveals that 'Eerie Elementary is alive' - a living, breathing monster.

questions.question: What does Sam use to defeat the monster mouth during the play?
questions.explanation: Sam kicks a giant drum of peanut butter into the mouth, which gums up the teeth.

questions.question: When Sam fell asleep on hall monitor duty, he woke up to find ---.
options: the halls dark and the school coming alive
questions.explanation: When Sam woke up, 'The halls were dark, nearly pitch black' and locker doors were slamming open and shut.

questions.question: Sam's locker smelled terrible because ---.
options: the school was breathing on it
questions.explanation: The smell was like 'really bad breath' - it was the living school breathing through the locker.

questions.question: Mr. Nekobe was Eerie Elementary's first hall monitor, and now he ---.
options: is too old and weak to fight the school alone
doesn't believe the school is alive
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe says 'I am old and weak, and the school knows it' - that's why Sam must take over.

questions.question: The school planned to attack during the play because ---.
options: hundreds of people were gathered in one place to eat
questions.explanation: The school is hungry and 'it has not fed in a long time.' The play brings hundreds of people together.

questions.question: During the play, the stage turned into a monster with ---.
options: giant teeth made of hundreds of folding chairs
questions.explanation: Hundreds of metal folding chairs were 'opening and closing like a set of giant, jagged teeth.'

questions.question: Antonio's lucky sandwich gave Sam the idea to use peanut butter because ---.
options: it fell into the monster mouth and slowed it down
questions.explanation: When Antonio's sandwich fell into the mouth and 'splattered against the chair teeth,' Sam saw how it slowed the monster.

questions.question: As hall monitor, Sam has special abilities that let him ---.
options: sense the school and feel what others cannot
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe says 'As hall monitor, you have the ability to sense the school, to see and feel and hear what others cannot.'

questions.question: The morning after the school attacked Sam, everything looked normal because ---.
questions.explanation: The school fixed itself: 'Everything was back to normal. It was like nothing had happened.'

questions.question: Sam didn't want to be hall monitor at first because ---.
questions.explanation: Sam says 'everyone hates the hall monitor' and he has to yell at people to get to class.

questions.question: To enter the secret room, Mr. Nekobe ---.
options: tugs twice on a light bulb
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe 'grabbed hold of a dim, swinging light bulb' and 'tugged twice' to open the secret door.

questions.question: When Sam put his hand against the wall in the secret room, he felt ---.
options: the wall gently swaying like the school was breathing
questions.explanation: Sam 'heard the soft sound of air blowing. And he felt it. The wall was gently swaying.' The school was breathing.

questions.question: During his training, Sam learned to defeat the machine by ---.
options: using things around him as shields and weapons
questions.explanation: Antonio told him 'Try using what's around you!' Sam grabbed a locker door as a shield.

questions.question: Lucy didn't believe Sam about the school because ---.
options: she was part of the school
she thought both Sam and Antonio were losing their minds
questions.explanation: Lucy 'thought both of her best friends were losing their minds' and 'wouldn't believe a word they said.'

questions.question: The school trapped the teachers and other students during the play by ---.
options: making the floorboards slide them into a closet
questions.explanation: The floorboards 'lifted up to form a slide' and Ms. Grinker and the students 'tumbled backward into the closet.'

questions.question: Antonio and Lucy were in danger during the play because ---.
options: they were hanging on wires above the monster mouth
questions.explanation: They were 'strung up on wires high above the stage' and the monster mouth was rising toward them.

questions.question: Sam got the peanut butter from ---.
questions.explanation: Sam ran to the lunchroom and into the kitchen where he found 'a giant drum of peanut butter.'

questions.question: In the lunchroom, Sam defended himself from water bottles using ---.
questions.explanation: Sam 'grabbed an orange lunch tray' and 'held it over his chest' as a shield.

questions.question: Mr. Nekobe couldn't help during the play attack because ---.
options: curtain ropes grabbed him and threw him into the closet
questions.explanation: The curtain ropes 'grabbed hold of' Mr. Nekobe and 'flung' him 'inside the closet.'

questions.question: Sam figured out the school would attack during the play when ---.
options: he read the play invitation and realized everyone would be gathered together
he had a dream about it
questions.explanation: When Sam read the play invitation, 'His heart began to pound. It all made sense. Sam knew exactly when the school would strike.'

questions.question: Lucy finally believed Sam when ---.
options: she saw the monster mouth for herself during the play
questions.explanation: Lucy saw the chair monster for herself during the play and worked with Sam to defeat it.

questions.question: What does Mr. Nekobe's statement that the school 'feeds on students' reveal about the danger?
options: The school is literally trying to eat and consume the students
questions.explanation: The school is a monster that actually eats students to survive. It's been hungry because 'it has not fed in a long time.'

questions.question: Why is it significant that the school can sense Sam just as Sam can sense it?
options: It means Sam is never truly safe because the school knows he is its enemy
Sam can talk to the school
The school wants to help Sam
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe warns 'the school can sense you too. It has attacked you twice already. It knows you are its enemy.'

questions.question: What theme does Sam's transformation from reluctant hall monitor to hero represent?
options: Accepting responsibility and rising to meet challenges can reveal hidden strength
questions.explanation: Sam didn't want the job but accepts it to protect his friends, discovering he has the courage to be a hero.

questions.question: Why might the author have made Antonio's silly lucky sandwich the key to defeating the monster?
options: It shows that even seemingly useless things can become important, and friendship provides unexpected solutions
questions.explanation: The 'ridiculous' lucky sandwich gives Sam the idea that saves everyone, showing how friends help each other unexpectedly.

questions.question: What does the school's ability to repair itself overnight suggest about the challenge Sam faces?
options: The school is easy to defeat
The fight is never truly over because the school always recovers and returns
questions.explanation: Even after Sam defeats the school's attacks, it repairs itself, suggesting this is an ongoing battle with no permanent victory.

questions.question: Why is it important that no one except Sam, Antonio, and Mr. Nekobe knows the school is alive?
options: It creates isolation and Sam must protect people who don't believe him and wouldn't understand
The school told them to keep quiet
questions.explanation: Sam has to protect people like Lucy who think he's 'crazy,' making his role lonelier and more challenging.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'The school knows that now is the time to strike' reveal about the conflict?
options: The school is intelligent and strategic, waiting for the right moment when its enemy is weak
Mr. Nekobe is controlling the school
questions.explanation: The school is calculating and intelligent, sensing that Mr. Nekobe is old and weak and choosing to attack when vulnerable.

questions.question: Why does Sam tell himself 'I'll never make it' but then find a solution?
options: Moments of doubt are normal, but thinking creatively helps overcome obstacles
questions.explanation: Sam almost gives up but remembers his training - 'Try using what's around you!' - and finds a creative solution.

questions.question: What is ironic about Sam's role in the play being a 'friendly pirate'?
options: He has almost no lines but ends up being the hero who saves everyone during the performance
questions.explanation: Antonio jokes that Sam has 'the worst part' with few lines, but Sam becomes the most important person when disaster strikes.

questions.question: What does Mr. Nekobe passing responsibility to Sam represent about growing up?
options: Young people must eventually take on responsibilities that older generations can no longer handle
questions.explanation: Mr. Nekobe is 'old and weak' and must pass his duty to Sam, representing how young people inherit responsibilities.

questions.question: Why does the school attack specifically when the curtain closes during the play?
options: The audience can't see what's happening, giving the school cover to attack without witnesses
questions.explanation: With the curtain closed, 'The audience can't see the stage' - the school attacks when no adults can witness or interfere.

questions.question: What lesson does Sam's training teach about facing challenges?
options: Practice and preparation help you think clearly when real danger comes
questions.explanation: Sam's training with the machine prepares him to think creatively under pressure when the real attacks happen.

questions.question: Why is it significant that Sam says 'I couldn't have done it without you two' at the end?
options: It shows that even heroes need friends and teamwork to succeed
Lucy and Antonio did all the work
He's lying to make them feel good
questions.explanation: Despite being the 'chosen one,' Sam acknowledges that his friends' help was essential to victory.

questions.question: What does the heartbeat sound from the clock symbolize?
options: The school is literally alive with a beating heart like a living creature
questions.explanation: The heartbeat emphasizes that Eerie Elementary isn't just magical - it's a living organism with a heart.

questions.question: Why might the author have made Antonio believe Sam even when Lucy doesn't?
options: Best friends support each other even when things seem unbelievable, showing the strength of their friendship
questions.explanation: Antonio helps Sam train even while saying 'I'm still not sure we aren't crazy,' showing true friendship means supporting first.

questions.question: What is the significance of Sam needing to 'trust' Lucy when he leaves her during the attack?
options: Heroes must sometimes leave loved ones in danger to get help, requiring mutual trust
questions.explanation: Sam has to leave Lucy and Antonio in danger to get peanut butter, saying 'Just trust me' - trust is essential.

questions.question: What does the setting of an old, crumbling school contribute to the horror atmosphere?
options: The decaying appearance suggests something wrong and ancient, making the school seem more menacing
questions.explanation: The school is described as 'an old castle made of crumbling red brick' with 'chipped paint' - decay suggests evil.

questions.question: Why is it meaningful that Sam's mom doesn't believe his story about the school?
options: It emphasizes that Sam must face this challenge without adult help, making him more alone but also more heroic
questions.explanation: When Sam's mom says 'Tell me the real reason,' it shows Sam can't rely on adults and must handle this himself.

questions.question: What does Mr. Nekobe mean when he calls Sam 'the school's enemy'?
options: Sam is the only one who can stop the school from harming students, making him the monster's target
questions.explanation: As hall monitor, Sam is the school's natural opponent - the one person chosen and able to fight it.

questions.question: What is the overall message of The School Is Alive?
options: Ordinary kids can become heroes when they accept responsibility, trust their friends, and face their fears
questions.explanation: Sam goes from an ordinary kid who hates his job to a hero who saves everyone, showing anyone can rise to challenges.
